resource.chars:
In each <s>polype <\s> zooid - there is <s>at one side <\s> at one point a ganglion 
(d) with a mass of deepred otolithes - As in <s>[text?<\s> Salpae this must be called 
<s>[text?]<\s > the ventral side - the opposite is the dorsal 
side and contains (as in Salpa) an endostyle 
<s>[text?]<\s> (III figs 1 & 2. c)
The ganglionic or ventral surfaces of all the 
polypes <s>(<\s> are turned the same way <s>)<\s> and towards 
the open end of the cylinder 
By far the greater part of the space occupied by each zooid 
<s>polype <\s>, is taken up by the respiratory cavity - This 
is elliptical and compressed laterally - It is 
lined by the proper branchial network hereafter 
to be described (u) and communicates freely by
means of the apertures in the branchial network 
with the post branchial or anal cavity - which 
as before stated opens into the interior of the 
cylinder 
The viscera lie behind the branchiae - they 
consist of the <s>[text?]<\s> digestive canal, heart, and generative organs.
The intestine (r.s.2-) commences by a wide mouth 
with thick lips - at the posterior ventral extremity of the respiratory 
cavity - The oesophagus (r) runs back and then <s>[text?]<\s> 
upwards to terminate in the wide <s>quadrangular <\s> subquadrilateral 
stomach (c) A narrow pylorus communicates 
with the intestine - which faces at first upwards 
and forwards and then suddenly becoming bent 
upon itself runs downwards and to the right 
side to end in the wide flattened anus (s)
The oesophagus is dotted over with branched 
carmine pigment cells - and similar cells 
are frequently seen upon the intestine just 
beyond the pylorus 
A tubular anus (m) arises from the stomach, and
